comment_text:
This video has been re-uploaded because I made an error in the last one. I said ashes have sodium hydroxide in them, when they really have potassium carbonate, which is converted to potassium hydroxide by treatment with calcium hydroxide or oxide.

I hate having to reupload, but the error was too big for me to let go. I do not like the idea of spreading misinformation. I hope you guys can understand!

I used to work at a big grease plant and the most common oil we used was hydrogenated castor oil, at least for the basic lithium soap I cooked. They had two other major types of grease. One was called poly-urea and the other contained a large proportion of bentonite and was called aeroshell. There were dozens of different additives like these weird plastic goos, metals like molybdenum or aluminum, pigments,  graphite, and once I used a large amount of acetic acid which I thought was odd. It was added after the lithium had already been pressure contacted with the solid castor oil and some thinning oil, like a bituminous oil or something like that. We used some oil that smelled really off. Every couple of weeks the whole place would smell like a Chinese restaurant and jalapenos. I swear we got recycled oil from restaurants or something. That place was so huge, but it's gone now, up in smoke.
A very nice video, thank-you!

Hot process completes saponification faster and so can be safely used after you finish the cook. Cold process should finish saponification within about 48 hours and then is safe to use. Finishing saponification and curing are two different things. Cure is more about letting the excess water evaporate making the bars harder and more long lasting. Both cold and hot process soap take 4-6 weeks to cure. In fact, many times hot process soap benefits from a longer cure time than cold process because it is generally made with more water.

So, let's talk about what you said about the sodium hydroxide. I work with hundreds of gallons of the stuff everyday (in a 50% concentration in water), and what you said about washing is off right away making everything fine... is 100% correct. I tell my guys the same thing; that if they think they might have splashed a little on their skin to just drop what they're doing and go rinse it off and they will be fine. It does take a little while for it to start eating through the outer, dead layers of your skin. And if it is dry, then it just can't eat into you. HOWEVER, the bigger problem we have is when we have a small leak and dries on something in a thin layer, and then someone touches it with bare skin. Then an hour later, they get sweaty or wet but not enough to rinse it off, and then it will get activated and start eating at them. This is why that whole part of the plant is strictly "gloves always." It's too easy to touch it while it's dry, forget about it, and then get sweaty or touch your eyes and wind up getting awful chemical burns.

This is also why in fight club we see Tyler Durden slowly lick his lips to give Edward Norton a big, sloppy, wet kiss on his hand before dumping the lye on him (It's unclear if he's using NaOH or KOH lye, since in soap making can use either, but they should act about the same). While the lye started acting on his skin way too quickly to be realistic, I do think that if you poured straight, undiluted caustic soda onto wet skin and then sat there and didn't wash it off, it could absolutely do some really nasty damage to your skin like that. It burns, but it starts slow and sneaks up on you several minutes later. I don't know about it puffing up like in the movie, that always looked more to me like keloid formation than any sort of chemical burn, and IME caustic soda doesn't really make your skin puff up like a pork rind. But I have seen and taken photos of people (for examples for my safety training) who have had some pretty horrible chemical burns from the stuff, and it's basically always from trying to ignore it instead of just rinsing it off immediately. Luckily, I haven't had to deal with anyone who had anything that caused any serious or long-term disfigurement or blindness or anything like that, but once you start to feel that burn you have already started to cause damage and it needs to be cleaned immediately (and I stress this all the time. I would much rather have something be done 5 minutes late because they stopped to go rinse off caustic they touched with a ripped glove than have them in pain and potentially scarred!). But there are loads of photos online of people who have gotten some horrific burns from lye.

My point is, telling people that sodium hydroxide is safe to handle with bare hands is not responsible advice to give out. You likely washed your hands before that lye was able to get wetted and start doing its thing. It can absolutely fuck up your day or even your life if you get it in your eyes or it disfigures you. You don't need to be terrified of it, as it's not going to jump out of the glass and attack you with a knife, but downplaying it that much is a bit too far. I also notice that you seem to be handling an almost pelletized form of it, which is probably safer, because it's not going to stick to dry skin. But if you are working with it dissolved in a liquid or a powdered form that can actually stick to dry skin, then I absolutey guarantee you that it will not be nearly so kind to bare skin. I am speaking from personal experience as well as from experience training people to work with it for a couple of years, now.

One other thing, though, that is realistic from that scene in Fight Club? Vinegar. We absolutely use Vinegar to neutralize NaOH spills so we can then either mop the smaller ones up or run the larger ones over with our floor sweeper to clean up! It's cheap, fairly safe, and while the smell is certainly strong, it's at least a "clean-smelling" kind of strong (and it goes away pretty quickly if you air out the area).

RIGHT, as a soap maker, I really would suggest people covering arms, legs, and hands when making soap. Sure, I respect Nile (he knows what he is on about) when he says Lye in solid form is okay to hold and you won't get hurt, but your skin has water and oils on it, so after a while, it will start to burn you. Always wear safety gear, I have seen some nasty burns and even people losing eyes from it, so it's not just a pretty hobby to do. I couldn't use cinnamon anything in soap as it can cause skin issues, even burns in the eyes, and its bad form to mix anything like this in glass as lye solution can etch glass. and it shatters. respect the soap, its not easy to make and it can be a b*tch if you don't pay attention. There are lots of videos and websites that are out there if you want to know more but respect the chemicals, it's a chemical process at the end of the day. For making solid soap I use cold process, sodium hydroxide,  and beef tallow with other fats, and added stuff for scent and moisturizing. For say when I make a shave soap, I use a lye mixture, around 70% potassium hydroxide and 30% sodium hydroxide, plus my fats and such to the soap recipe. The potassium hydroxide makes it more of a cream yet firm soap... and this is done hot process with a considerable amount of stearic acid... which also affects texture of the soap... also very much improves how it lathers into a shaving cream with a shave brush.

These types of soaps aren't that great for extended cleaning because they tend to be rather alkaline as the final product yes it cleans but at the cost of your hydro-lipid barrier. Your skin is actually pretty acidic sitting around 4.5 to 5.5 so when you introduce an alkaline on a regular it has the potential to disrupt the skins hydro-lipid barrier. Since these soaps are so basic there are no pH adjusters in them to lower the pH so these types of soaps can cause disruptions in the hydro-lipid barrier which can lead to bad sensitivities, redness, rashes. acne, infections etc basically your shield against the world has been stripped away.

Adding things like Cinnamon and Lavender just makes it worse as well because both are known irritants so not only does the soap potentially disrupt barrier function it might cause even more irritation. Formulators usually formulate essential oils in really low quantities sometimes below 1% of the total volume of a formulation to try to avoid irritation but it still happens in some people.

Okay...great to know that touching NaOH with your bare skin won’t immediately cause damage, but honestly...you shouldn’t have told folks this is possible. Some idiot that doesn’t have the common sense you and I do could do a lot of damage. Same with touching the lye water—practice what’s smart...not necessarily what’s possible. PPE SHOULD ALWAYS BE USED WHEN MAKING SOAP WITH LYE: closed-toe shoes, pants, long sleeves, gloves with the sleeves tucked into the gloves, and goggles. Pull back long hair. Pets and children...and people who don’t respect corrosive chemicals and hot liquids should not be allowed in the room. Dissolve lye into water in a well-ventilated area juuuuust to be sure you don’t breathe in anything toxic. Don’t use aluminium, don’t use wood/bamboo, and be cautious of thin plastics; glass, silicone, ceramics, thick/sturdy plastics, and stainless steel are okay. Also, I’m not sure using BITTER almond oil was a wise decision: BITTER almonds are poisonous, but SWEET almonds are fine. This is true in ingesting, but I don’t know about topical use.
This is coming from someone who’s studied soap making for ten years and made soap for 6 years. I also have a scar from a chemical burn from lye because—guess what—I wasn’t wearing appropriate PPE. I’d been making soap for a few years and got too comfortable.

Note: when you get concentrated NaOH/KOH on your skin, do NOT wash it just once.
Wash *until the skin stops feeling slippery*.

It gets soapy because the base (KOH) reacts with fats secreted by your skin, producing glycerol and some surfactants - soap, essentially.
And if lye is concentrated enough to hydrolize fat, it's concentrated enough to (at the very least) dry out your skin and exacerbate any skin issues you have.


If you work with lye AND toxic compounds, keep in mind one little-known toxicology fact: surfactants tend to increase chemical permeability of your skin.
Which means that anything toxic or mutagenic has a much easier time getting through the protective layer down into your tissues.
So don't leave any leftover soap or KOH on your skin when working with benzene.
Not even if you wear gloves.
Gloves can sometimes have holes, as I've learned the hard way.

In my case, I was hasty one day when working with some pretty concentrated KOH and benzene.
I didn't notice my glove had a teeny-tiny hole near the middle finger. I also didn't pay attention to the steadily worsening itching in my finger: I usually had that reaction to gloves.
I only took off the glove at the end of the lesson - and saw that my skin was both soapy and had that tangy smell of benzene to it.
Massive, albeit fortunately local, inflammation ensued a couple days later; my fingernail was spoon-shaped for three years after I got that crap to subside, and my usually mild eczema got exacerbated to blood-seeping-from-cracked-flesh levels of unpleasant.

I'm pretty sure the acute inflammation and the deformed fingernail is just what happens when a finger gets an hour-long meet-and-greet with concentrated KOH, but the eczema was probably made much, much worse by the surfactant-benzene combination.

So here's my opinion to this recipe:
1. too much water - you use 83,3% liquid oils -> reduce the water or you will have a very soft soap
2. the supererfat (not saponized fats) is under 5% which is not good for your skin. Use it only with gloves and to clean objects. For handsoap you should get at least 8-25% superfat so it doesn't damage your skin that would be a max of 78g NaOH fot this batch, use a diamond scale for the NaOH so you get it exact!!! Very important
3. this soap will not get much bubbles when washing because of the high amount of olive oil - so use a better recipe for the oils regarding their qualities
4. DO NOT TOUCH THE FRICKING NaOH!!!!!! WEAR GLOVES AND GLASSES!!!! As soon as it gets to the air it will suck in water and that will produce horrible skinburn
5. slowly give the NaOH to the water, it may start boiling if put in too fast -> lye everywhere, maybe in your eyes!
6. do this in a well ventilated area, the fumes are not good for your lungs
7. when adding the lye look for the oils and lye to have the same temperature
8. this soap will at least need half a year to be okay to use - before it just will produce slime between your hands
9. essential cinnamon oil is irritating to the skin and mucosa, you should not use it in soap
10. 3% to weight essential oil is commonly used
11. food coloring will not hold it's color - use specially made pigments for coloring so you won't be disappointed later
12. Menhol is also irritating for the skin - especially in this concentration
13. use a spatula when scraping the soap out of the container - it will make things way more easy
14. when taking the soap out of the moulds it is not safe for the skin -> use gloves!
15. when you see the mould sticking onto the soap - let it sit for a while longer or freeze it - let it thaw after that for 5 minutes - > they will come out way better
16. don't just wait 4-6 weeks, the soap may be safe then, but not pretty good. it will wash away fast and you will be using more than needed. let them dry out at least three months in a cool, dark, well ventilated area
17. put them on a wood rack or cooling rack the guarantee the air ventilation - so you won't have to flip it and it can breathe thoroughly

Some slight misinformation in this video. Both hot process and cold process soap need the 4 to 6 week cure time to let water evaporate and become a harder bar. Hot process soap saponifies quicker than cold process soap, but they can both be used after 24-48 hours (after all the lye saponifies). Saponification is not the same as curing. If you don't want to have a bar that will just disappear in the shower after a few washes you will need to let them both cure the 4 to 6 weeks. Check out Kevin Dunn for more information about this.

I just made soap just because I wanted to give it a shot. Did it in my kitchen using an old croc pot, lye, and pure coconut oil (no vegetable oils). Then I added some lavender essential oil drops.
Mixed it all up while it cooked on the croc pot and when it was a medium thick, I transferred it into a glass baking dish, then I baked it on low temp. When it was solid, I let it cure for a week. Because it was purely coconut oil and essential oil, it made pure white bars.

A cool thing happened when it baked too, the top surface of it bubbled slightly, so the the top surface of the bars has this frothy look. I thought it looked kind of neat, wasnt intentional, but it looked great.

One funny thing I read about testing if your soap is done, is to lick it. If you get "zapped" when you lick it, the reaction of the lye is still taking place, and it reacted to the moisture on your tongue. I tried this out and yeah, it felt like licking a battery. Left it to cure for a couple more days and second test (yeah I licked it again lol), it tasted my soap.

Best soap i've ever used. I made probably a years worth with this batch.

There's a variation of your cold process here that's debateably a hot process that produces a different kind of soap that is colloquially called "neat soap" It has different properties, being harder for one, and a more consistent lather for two.

Basically through the magic of thermal control (watch out when you add the basic material) you keep the temperature above 150F and below 212F. If the water boils it changes the structure into something else. Holding it at this temperature for an hour or three and then cooling it off as slowly as possible will yield micelles that are shaped a little differently and arranged in more of a planar shape. I accomplished this by adding the NaOH to water and pouring it in hot. That's my method at least. In the book "Scientific Soap Making: The Chemistry of the Cold Process" by Kevin Dunn, he dedicates a whole chapter on the topic and has some nifty pictures to explain it. I loaned my copy out and it hasn't returned so I can't quote him.

The technical definition is neat soap is a lamellar structure containing much soap and little water.

It was my favorite part of soap making when I got to use calculus to find the optimal mix of oils and then more calculus to figure out how much NaOH and water to use to keep the thermals under control. (Spoiler alert, trial and error worked better for small scale production). Since I used beeswax in my oil mix as a hardener, I had to start the process hot. But you could skip the beeswax and do it somewhat cold if you have softer waxes and oils to work with (like coconut oil 72 or olive oil).

There are also soap foams (ivory soap, it floats cause of air lowering its buoyancy) which lather more effectively but is just whipped or air injected solid soap. The increase in lather is due to an increase in surface area (I believe, no expert).

These are rarely mentioned in chemistry classes when they talk about saponification, at least from my experience.

Common methods of making soap :

(A) Using esters:
Esters are substances which have a sweet, fruity smell. They are used in perfumes. To make esters, you will need:
Acetic (Ethanoic)Acid (CH3COOH)
Sodium Hydroxide(NaOH)
Ethanol(C2H5OH)
Hot, concentrated sulphuric acid(H2SO4)

(1)CH3COOH+C2H5OH(Sulphuric Acid Catalyst)----->CH3COOC2H5(Ester)+H2O

(2)CH3COOC2H5+NaOH----->CH3COONa(Sodium acetate) +Ethanol

Sodium acetate is our soap.

(B)Acid-Base Neutralization:
Adding sodium hydroxide directly to acetic acid,

NaOH+CH3COOH--->CH3COONa+H2O

Thus we can conclude that soap is a sodium salt of long chain carboxylic acids.

(C)Using metal carbonates/hydrogencarbonates:

For this it is simpler to use baking soda(NaHCO3).
To obtain baking soda, you will need common salt(NaCl),water,carbon dioxide and ammonia(NH3).

NaCl+H2O+CO2+NH3---->NH4Cl(Ammonium Chloride) + NaHCO3

Adding acetic acid to the baking soda,

CH3COOH+NaHCO3----->CH3COONa+H2O+CO2

The basic formula for soap is CH3COONa. However, you will find that the formula for the soap you use may be C15H31COONa or C17H35COONa.
Thus we can say that the general formula for soap is C(n)H(2n+1)COONa, where 'n' is the number of atoms in the molecule.

Thank you.

My grandma used to make a lot of soap (kg's of soap/week) from animal fat and sulphuric acid. She usually dilute it with water and place it in a huge pot. Then she would start a fire under the pot and put animal fat inside the pot. Boiling it would evaporate the water and transform the fat in liquid so sulphuric acid could disolve it. After most of the water was evaporated, she would stop the fire and let the soap form in a solid layer on top of the solution. She would then cut it with a knife and removve it and clean it with some water to remove the leftover acid.

This was considered industrial soap. It also had a specific smell. But you can use it to wash with it tho...
